executive_summary: Paper product manufacturers convert purchased paper and paperboard into a variety of products, including cigarette papers, playing cards, wrapping paper and paper novelties. Manufacturers also mold purchased pulp into egg cartons, food trays, dishes, florist pots and other products. In recent years, import penetration has increased, forcing manufacturers to compete with lower-cost substitutes. Companies have responded to competition by consolidating operations through merger and acquisition activity.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumer preferences are shifting as they learn more about the environmental effects of disposable products. Consumers across all demographics prefer to purchase food and beverage products with recyclable and biodegradable packaging. Molded pulp products and paperboard containers are a recyclable alternative to plastic packaging, and they have thus been embraced by eco-conscious consumers as such.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Paper Product Imports Have Increased as the US Dollar Has Strengthened Over the Past Five Years
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Competition from low-priced imports has climbed over the past five years. Import penetration into the industry has risen, with imports satisfying roughly one-quarter of industry demand. Price-based competition has resulted in steady import growth aided by an appreciating US dollar, which makes imported goods relatively less expensive domestically.

Rising input costs have led to volatile purchase costs for manufacturers, putting downward pressure on profit. The world price of wood pulp has been unstable over the past five years, in addition to natural gas and crude oil prices, which have spiked. This trend was exacerbated by the war in Ukraine in 2022, as economic sanctions on Russia led to a strained supply of natural resources.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: An Expansion of Product Offerings Will Increase Operating Costs and Limit Declines in Industry Revenue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Manufacturers are expected to adopt more sustainable processes in response to consumers' growing environmental concerns. There will be efforts to increase the use of recycled materials and reduce energy consumption and waste disposal in the production process. Many companies will focus on research and development to discover cost-effective methods for gas reduction and oil consumption, raw materials and resources consumption and seamless integration of recycled materials in paper product manufacturing.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A Weakening US Dollar Will Sink Industry Imports But Exports Are Set to Climb
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Industry revenue will decline despite limited competition from imports. Industry demand will lag as consumer preferences shift away from disposable products. A decline in the value of the US dollar will affect trade demand, making imports increasingly expensive for consumers. Exports are expected to push up as a weakening US dollar makes industry products more affordable for international consumers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consolidation Persists as Smaller Manufacturers Get Pushed Out
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Paper product manufacturers will continue consolidating as extensive acquisition activity continues. With continued consolidation and company exits, market share concentration will grow and the number of enterprises will be reduced. Companies will focus on hiring skilled workers and achieving economies of scale to get through this pressurized period. Profit is expected to fall slightly but remain relatively stable over the next five years as key input costs increase.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry convert purchased paper and paperboard into a variety of products, including playing cards, wrapping paper, cigarette papers, paper filters, paper novelties, die-cut paper shapes and recycled paper insulation. Industry manufacturers also mold purchased pulp into egg cartons, food trays, cups and dishes, florists' pots and other products.

negative_impact_factors: Industry Assistance Level is low - steady

key_trends: Import levels are increasing, putting pressure on domestic manufacturers.
Exports have decreased as the US dollar value has increased, making domestic products more expensive for foreign consumers.

Consumers wish to minimize their environmental impact, so they gravitate toward eco-friendly products. Companies that effectively market environmentally friendly products will outperform others during the outlook period.
Many environmental protection regulations are put in place to ensure responsible manufacturing practices. These regulations are aimed at reducing air, water and noise pollution.
Strict regulations can affect the industry by limiting the supply of materials. High compliance requirements increase operating costs for manufacturers.

Consumers ate at home more often during the COVID-19 pandemic, so demand for molded pulp goods for food packaging temporarily increased. Demand for party supplies and accessories declined because of stay-at-home orders.

Wholesalers make up the largest market segment because they have long-term contracts with manufacturers. Wholesalers distribute products to fast food restaurants, coffee and snack shops, hotels and motel businesses.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Paper product manufacturers primarily sell finished products directly to wholesalers for domestic and international distribution. Wholesalers distribute products to fast food restaurants, coffee and snacks shops, hotels and motels and businesses. Manufacturers sign long-term contracts with wholesalers, so that revenue share is relatively stable. However, declines from the restaurant sector amid the pandemic caused this market to shrink over the past five years.

For product distribution, manufacturers sell to retailers like large supermarket chains and grocery stores. Retailers have benefited from technological development and globalization, which has enabled manufacturers to interact directly with consumers. The COVID-19 pandemic shuttered food service locations and limited growth in demand for paper products.

Paper product manufacturers produce items like liquid packaging containers, cartons, cigarette paper and other miscellaneous products. Manufacturers, primarily those operating in the liquid beverage, milk, ice cream and egg industries, incorporate these products into end-use products. Large companies have become vertically integrated and can manufacture food and liquid packaging products internally, limiting demand growth for end-use products from manufacturers.

products_and_services.product_description: Fast food restaurants, motels and other service establishments use molded pulp food products for transporting food and beverages. These products include egg cartons, florist pots and packaging for various goods. Molded pulp packaging has grown in popularity in recent years due to increased utility and environmental concerns, but the product poses serious problems. These products require wood to produce, so they significantly contribute to deforestation. The manufacturing process also produces chemical emissions that are released into the atmosphere. Still, the products are a better alternative to comparable plastic products.

products_and_services.product_or_service: PARTY SUPPLIES AND HOLIDAY GOODS AND ACCESSORIES
products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes party goods like novelties, displays, decorations and party hats, as well as similar holiday decorations and supplies. Most of these products are bought seasonally, with demand spiking near the December holiday season. Party supplies and holiday goods are sensitive to income fluctuations, as consumers don't like to spend on discretionary products in times of economic strain. COVID-19 restrictions hindered purchases of these products by limiting social gatherings in an effort to mitigate health risks.

Converted paper and paperboard products include die-cut paper and paperboard products, such as fillers and flats for egg cases (except molded pulp), bottle caps, closures and lids, placemats, tray dollies, unprinted cards and folders and mounts, excluding office products. These paper products are mainly sold to other manufacturing industries to use in bottle and food packaging and demand for them depends on food-based manufacturing activity. Additional paper and paperboard products include: unprinted tags, table skirts, tickets and labels, draperies, fine crepe paper, other miscellaneous items. Other paper products include cigarette paper, coffee filters and cellulose insulation products. Tobacco consumption has trended downward over the past decade, but cigarettes typically fare well during economic downturns since consumers are under more pressure and use tobacco products as stress relievers. During the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, demand for cigarette papers increased. Unprocessed paper pulp products are articles of pulp that are not molded or pressed and are sold without further manufacturing or specification. These articles require minimal labor and as a result, have been less affected by competitively priced imports that benefit from lower labor costs.

tier_1_suppliers: Wood Pulp Mills in the US
Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing in the US
Organic Chemical Manufacturing in the US
Printing, Paper, Food, Textile & Other Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Cigarette & Tobacco Manufacturing in the US
Paper Bag & Disposable Plastic Product Wholesaling in the US
Office Stationery Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Molded Pulp Goods are Considered an Ecological Alternative to Plastic Products

international_trade_points.trade_description: China is the largest source of imported paper products in 2024. China accounts for over one-third of imported paper products. Over the past decade, the Chinese forestry and paper products market has developed at a rapid rate, producing high-quality products at low prices. Foreign investors, including US companies, are progressively moving production to China and importing finished products to the United States. Imported paper goods are cheaper. Imports have increased due to rising production costs in the United States. Foreign operators benefit from low labor and lower purchase costs, providing them with higher profit. When the value of the US dollar is high, imports can be more affordable for domestic consumers.

Exports have declined as the value of the US dollar increases. A stronger US dollar leads to export declines as it makes US products more expensive to import. Over the past decade, US paper products, such as paper novelties, have become less competitive in the global market, with other countries opting to import from Asian competitors. The value of exports has decreased partially due to pandemic-related economic disruption. The United States distributes over two-thirds of its total exports to Canada and Mexico. These nations have strong trade relationships with the United States and the proximity of US products makes them more attractive, especially during times of high fuel and freight costs.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region has the highest percentage of establishments (around 30%) compared to its share of the population (around 15%). This suggests that the Great Lakes region is home to a significant number of manufacturers or business establishments relative to its population. The text further elaborates that Indiana (5.1%), Illinois (5.1%), and Wisconsin (3.4%) are the largest producers of paper products in the Great Lakes region. However, it mentions that other states in the region also have paper product manufacturing plants in operation. The establishments are often located near paper and paperboard mills to lower material transportation costs, and such establishments are abundant in the Great Lakes region.

The Southeast is the region most saturated with paper product manufacturers. Manufacturers have been attracted to this region for its low labor costs, growing population levels and proximity to large ports and suppliers. North Carolina (3.4%) and Florida (4.8) are home to the largest number of establishments in the region.

Most western establishments are in California. California accounts for 11.3% of US paper product manufacturing plants, almost double the number of establishments in Pennsylvania (5.9%), the country's second-largest operating state. The West, and California in particular, are attractive to manufacturers due to high population levels, raw material availability and proximity to shipping ports.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Cellulose manufacturing for insulation is highly regulated by the US government. CPSC standards are based on critical radiant flux, corrosiveness, settled density and smoldering combustion.

The Clean Water Act is the primary law governing pollution control of waterways in the United States. The Solid Waste Disposal Act created institutional mechanisms and incentives for properly disposing of solid and hazardous waste.
Manufacturers are subject to specific provisions relating to airborne pollution emissions. The CAA is designed to protect and enhance the nation's air resources to protect public health and welfare.
The EPA's Cluster Rule is a multimedia (air and water) regulation to mitigate air and water pollution from the pulp and paper industry, where emissions and discharges are closely linked.

Noise pollution is regulated by federal law to protect public health and welfare. The law lists the types of industrial machinery considered and requires the EPA to coordinate the programs relating to noise research and noise control.

basis_points.basis_description: Larger companies are absorbing small operators to expand their reach. By expanding operations, operators can achieve economies of scale and secure key inputs at a faster rate.
Competition from substitutes has put pressure on industry revenue. Paper products imports have increased over the past five years.

concentration_points.concentration_description: There are no formal tariffs on imported pulp and paper products, so countries can export to the United States duty-free. Imports of cigarette papers may be subject to the federal excise tax on cigarettes.

concentration_points.concentration_title: US manufacturers compete on price basis
concentration_points.concentration_description: US manufacturers compete with imported products on a price basis. Countries with fewer regulations have lower operating costs and can offer competitive pricing.
The biggest manufacturers have expanded their reach by purchasing smaller, struggling companies or merging with other operators.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Natural gas and crude oil are used for energy when converting raw wood and wood chips into paper products and are constantly fluctuating in price. This, in addition to the volatility in the price of wood pulp, has constricted profit.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wage Costs Lag Due to Labor Productivity Improvements From Technological Innovation
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages make up an estimated 12.1% of revenue in 2024, down from 14.2% in 2019. Employment has trended downward over the past decade, due to labor productivity improvements from technological innovation.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are the most significant cost for manufacturers
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs account for 44.5% of revenue in 2024, up from 42.6% in 2019. The primary materials used in production include paper, paperboard, pulp, glues, printing inks, plastic packaging and chemicals like sulfur, chlorine, lime and soda ash, among others.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Utility costs are high due to the energy-intensive nature of manufacturing
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Utility costs are anticipated to account for 2.6% of revenue in 2024, remaining relatively steady over the past five years. Utility costs include expenses associated with heating, cooling and powering manufacturing facilities and office spaces.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: It is challenging to secure the right mixture of staff required to run operations efficiently. Typical employees include designers, engineers, floor staff and managers. Skilled professionals working in manufacturing are increasingly hard to find.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Driven by global economic changes, the prices of key inputs like gas, oil and wood pulp are highly volatile. Revenue is highly influenced by and often changes in line with the world price of wood pulp.

Stay-at-home orders and social distancing guidelines significantly reduced social gatherings in 2020, which limited demand for paper products. Declines in demand from the restaurant sector amid the pandemic limited industry revenue growth in 2020.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad? How has the coronavirus pandemic affected import competition?
FAQs.answer: Since imports are rising, paper product companies are going to have to leverage their geographic advantages. Low-priced imports contribute to intensifying price-based competition.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy? How has your company's performance been affected by the coronavirus pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Paper product companies' sales are heavily dependent on the health of the US economy. The coronavirus pandemic has likely negatively impacted their performance due to economic disruptions.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Locking in long-term supply contracts can help paper product companies combat volatility. The world price of wood pulp has been volatile in recent years, ultimately decreasing over the five years to 2023.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in locations with well-established infrastructure networks?
FAQs.answer: As acquisition activity has grown among paper product companies, exploring such opportunities has become a necessity.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisitions to expand product offerings?
FAQs.answer: Diversifying product lines can boost market share.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology, such as 3D printing, to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Since many paper products are uniform, anything that produces items more efficiently presents companies with an opportunity. Investment in technology can make the production process more efficient and increase profit long-term.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Automating operations reduces costs overall, spurring profit margin growth for paper product companies. Over the past five years, however, operational synergies from automation have been offset by input price volatility. Companies have also increased investment in research and development.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Reducing emissions is vital for any paper product company moving forward since consumers are looking for sustainable products. As a manufacturing industry, operators must comply with the Environmental Protection Agency's regulations.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to adjust to changing environmental standards? How has the shift from plastic affected demand for your company's paper products?
FAQs.answer: Being able to quickly pivot based on regulations can benefit paper product manufacturers. As consumers have avoided plastic products, demand for some paper products has increased.

FAQs.question: How has price volatility of inputs affected profit margins over the past 12 months? How has the pandemic affected profitability?
FAQs.answer: Wood prices have rapidly grown over the past five years, lowering the average industry profit margin. The average industry profit margin is expected to be 5.1% in 2023.

FAQs.question: What are the benefits of renewing supply contracts? Has your company contended with any significant disruptions in the supply chain during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Contract renewal is a great way of insuring against short-term revenue volatility for paper product companies. Established supply contracts protected some operators from volatility during the coronavirus pandemic.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain relationships with producers? How do you ensure you are getting the best deals in terms of supply?
FAQs.answer: A close association with a major paper mill or paperboard producer that can supply large volumes of quality paper is crucial to success in this industry. Amid the COVID-19 pandemic, operators contended with supply chain disruptions that limited the restocking of retailers' shelves.

FAQs.question: How do you change your input in response to cost changes? How often do you vary your input materials?
FAQs.answer: Using a combination of input materials in response to cost changes will minimize production costs and maximize profit.

FAQs.question: Who is your largest customer? How do you maintain good relations with key customers?
FAQs.answer: Having a large supply contract with key customers for bulk orders ensures that manufacturing plants produce at near maximum capacity. Growth in e-commerce sales during the pandemic led to increased demand for industry packaging products.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue comes from international trade? How do you make up for lost profit when the value of the US dollar is high?
FAQs.answer: When the value of US dollar is high, the industry typically suffers as imports penetrate the sector. Imports are expected to satisfy 34.0% of domestic demand in 2023.

FAQs.question: Do you have fixed, long term contracts with wood pulp suppliers? Are you able to absorb any increases in input costs?
FAQs.answer: Major industry companies typically have supply contracts to minimize the transfer of input price hikes. Companies both absorb and pass down input price hikes. Input price hikes, however, hurt the average industry profit margin. The world price of wood pulp is expected to decrease over the five years to 2023.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in overall consumer spending? How do changes in consumer spending influence demand for your products?
FAQs.answer: Given the discretionary nature of many industry products, rising consumer spending levels typically coincide with increased demand for paper product manufacturers. Although consumer spending during the pandemic declined, e-commerce surged, supporting demand for industry packaging materials and boxes.
